Today, CTG said goodbye to our revered CEO Jim Boldt, whose life was celebrated at a Mass of Christian Burial in Snyder, New York. The entire CTG family mourns his sudden passing earlier this week. Jim was a strong but humble leader who possessed an incredible memory, extraordinary business acumen, and an unparalleled commitment to CTG throughout his nearly 20 years of service to the Company. As CEO since 2001, Jim led CTG from difficult times to renewed success through his very capable direction and focused strategic vision for the company. We will all greatly miss Jim.

data.message: Come on CTG! Get on board the Walk for Wellness campaign.

Hey CTGers! Are you up for the challenge?! Our HR/Benefits team has developed a fun way to promote physical fitness and company team building. The “Walk for Wellness” challenge began on June 2 and continues through August 31 with an emphasis on combining physical fitness with CTG employee bonding (despite the fact that many of us are remote). 

Track your progress. Learn about other CTG locations. Boost your fitness level. Win prizes**! And get this, other cardio activities (i.e. tennis, aerobics, Zumba, basketball, soccer, biking, strength training, etc.) count too, provided you meet the required minimum minutes for that week’s route! 

** For each route you submit (# of required active minutes for that week), your name will be entered into a raffle to win Target or Home Depot gift cards: 
• 1st prize: $100 gift card
• 2nd prize: $50 gift card
• 3rd prize: $25 gift card 

Now lace up your shoes and get moving…then log your weekly activity minutes on the Walk for Wellness web page: https://ctgcentral.ctg.com/wellness/

data.message: GREAT JOB!

The Ride For Roswell is a healthy celebratory weekend of cycling fun that raises funds for cancer research patient care programs at Roswell Park Cancer Institute (a valued CTG client). It is the largest single-day cycling event in the U.S. (in terms of number of riders). Last year nearly 8,000 riders participated to raise $4 million. Funds raised provide seed funding for cancer research projects at Roswell and also support programs for patients and families.

The ‘Ride’ started in 1996 and CTG has had a team for each of the 19 years of the Ride! In 2013 CTG had 38 team members who raised $12,532 and CTG ranked #48 among the 700 teams in terms of fundraising! Kudos to our 2013 team (see photo).

This year’s race will be held June 27-28 and CTG has 42 team members committed who have raised $4,220 to date.

data.name: "CTG to Benefit as a Key User of the UB Center for Computational Research"

data.message: Getting a 500 error for the link here :/ Even when accessing the news from the feed of the homepage

data.caption: www.ctg.com

data.name: United Way of Buffalo & Erie County

data.message:
Did you hear that CTG is one of a few companies that will gain access to the State University of New York at Buffalo’s (UB) Center for Computational Research (CCR), which houses one of the world’s largest, most powerful supercomputers, among other supercomputing resources? 

CTG will become a key user of the CCR as part of several initiatives recently announced by Governor Andrew Cuomo, which seek to establish New York as a national leader in genomic medicine and develop new ways to treat, prevent, and manage serious diseases. 

Through this relationship with UB, we can further develop our medical informatics products and services with the help of the CCR’s supercomputers and big data infrastructure. It will also differentiate us in the emerging big data analytics market targeted to healthcare.

We have another Random Act of Kindness!: 

"My sister has a senior neighbor who is struggling to make it on just her social security. She lives in a rural area populated with only small grocers with very high prices and limited selection of healthy foods.

When she receives her Social Security check each month, we do her grocery shopping for her 'in the city' where we can buy almost twice the groceries for half the price. 

She is very grateful for the help and has commented on how much we save her, while still purchasing foods that are nutritious."

Got a Random Act of Kindness to share? Let us know!
Very cool!!! More people should be so kind!!!

data.message:
This week’s Random Act of Kindness comes from an anonymous CTGer who helped an elderly neighbor:

“I heard through our neighborhood grapevine that one of our elderly neighbors was worried about falling because the boards on his front stoop were cracked and broken. When I knew he wasn't going to be home for the day, I replaced the boards and made sure it was structurally safe. He was so surprised and happy! It made me happy too.”

What a wonderful thing to do for an elderly neighbor! 

If you or someone you know has gone above and beyond with a Random Act of Kindness, we’d love to hear from you.
Love this!!
Love seeing this!
Great act. Awesome!

This week’s Random Act of Kindness comes from Greg B., who shared an act of kindness towards his fellow servicemen.

“Several weeks ago, I had the opportunity to buy lunch for a couple of military members that were in the restaurant. As a retired military member, I try to take this opportunity to do this whenever it presents itself. I can also tell you definitively that the person you are buying it for will be appreciative. I’ve been there when an anonymous person bought my meal. It warms your heart when you know someone actually appreciates you and your family’s sacrifice. I encourage everybody to take this opportunity when you can. The sacrifices they are making are greater than many realize. It's time we show them the gratitude they have earned!”

What a truly inspiring story. Thank you Greg! 

If you or someone you know has gone above and beyond with a Random Act of Kindness, we’d love to hear from you.

Our Random Act of Kindness this week comes from Olaf in Belgium: 

Helping a senior driver 

I would like to add yesterday's act of kindness of my colleague Tom. A senior driver was blocked in one of the tunnels towards the exit from Brussels due to a broken clutch. Tom stopped and helped the driver by moving the car to safety to unblock the tunnel and then waited with the driver for the repair service for the car. Kudos. 

Thank you Olaf for your submission, and thank you Tom for helping someone in need!
Smelleken like ... Tom De Meester. Thanks Tom!

data.message:
As part of our Random Acts of Kindness initiative we’re picking an act performed by one of our team members to highlight each week. This week's Random Act of Kindness comes from Jane: 

Donating Miles about to Expire 

“I did not realize that I was able to donate miles that were about to expire. I didn't have enough airline miles to get a flight and they were about to expire in a few weeks. I thought: OK I can pay to make them last longer OR I can donate to a charity. Mine happened to be US Airways and they match the miles. I had 3 charities to choose from and I chose the "Fisher House" which is where families of injured military can stay while they are visiting their loved ones. You can also donate to Make-a-Wish Foundation and more. – Jane B.”

Thanks Jane! 

Would you like to share your Random Act of Kindness? We’d love to hear from you.
AWESOME!

data.name: George Saunders's Advice to Graduates
data.caption: 6thfloor.blogs.nytimes.com
data.message: Did you catch George Saunders' inspirational speech to Syracuse University graduates? In it he said, “What I regret most in my life are failures of kindness...I’d say, as a goal in life, you could do worse than: Try to be kinder.” Here at CTG, we’re taking this a step further with our Random Acts of Kindness initiative, and encouraging employees to report Random Acts of Kindness and inspire others to keep a great thing going. Keep an eye out for the Random Act of Kindness of the week posted on our page!

data.message:
There is still time to join CTG as it is again participating in the Ride for Roswell. CTG employees and their friends and families are encouraged to join our team. Last year our 34 riders raised $11,048, among the 7,200+ total cyclists who raised a total of $3.2 million for resarch and patient care at Roswell Park Cancer Institute.

This year the ride takes place on Friday and Saturday, June 22-23, and offers routes ranging from 3 to 104 miles! Visit the CTG Team page for more information.
data.description: The Ride is a year-round fundraising program for the Institute that culminates in a celebratory cycling event every June. It is a safe and healthy day of cycling fun for riders, teams, cancer survivors, and supporters.

data.name: Healthcare Job Rate Slows, But Technology Could Increase It  | News | Healthcare Informatics
data.caption: www.healthcare-informatics.com
data.message:
Healthcare Job Rate Slows, But Technology Could Increase It 

 

(7/15/2010)
Traditionally known as the one recession-proof industry, the health care job market has begun to slow in recent months. According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, only 9,000 new jobs were created in health care in June—up 1,000 from May but still well below the 2009 monthly average. The U.S. unemployment rate did drop in June, down to 9.5 percent, while a total of about 83,000 people were hired last month. Outplacement research firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas reported that "the pace of downsizing has slowed significantly from a year ago," although last month the number of layoffs edged up by 1.4 percent.
"Technology in health care may drive the next wave of hires," said John Burkhardt, Director of Operations at Seattle-based career website MedZilla.com, the internet's most established source for health care, pharmaceutical, and biotechnology job postings.

data.message: I love when Dave Trance comes up with fun, creative ideas like this one… LOVE when he does that!
I love being a part of an awesome team. I work with the most dedicated and fun women at CTG.

I LOVE my job!  It gives me great satisfaction to help people find their next job!  Being a Recruiter at CTG is awesome!!  Oh and did I mention I work with the BEST TEAM at CTG (lol)!!! . . . . you know who you are!!!

I think my favorite thing in what I do is working with a great set of customers who actually care about you as a person rather than just their "IT guy."  And when I have any questions, I get immediate support from my CTG HR site manager, which takes the stress level down on me tremendously.
I love working with the fabulous people in CTG's Syracuse Office!
I also love that an Elizabeth Martin and an Elizabeth Martin Savino can co-exist at the same company!!! Right, Elizabeth?
I love being able to work with a wide range of interesting people, both in and outside of CTG.
I LOVE it when CTG Recruiters post their open jobs on CTG Careers....woot, woot!

I LOVE that CTG has provided me with an opportunity to develop my career over the past 15 years.  I LOVE being challenged everyday, I LOVE being innovative, I LOVE solving problems and I LOVE all my colleagues........I really LOVE what I do!  Thank you CTG !

When I was growing up, the only thing I got in trouble for was talking too much in class. I love that I found a career in doing what I love: talking with and connecting with people. So if anyone wants to talk about open positions in the West Coast or Raleigh, NC-> Call me! = )
CTG loves Elizabeth Martins!  =)
I love the wonderful women that I work with in the Payroll department!!!!
I love working for Ed, best manager at CTG :)
I love the work and the colleagues!  Variety in all senses of the word :-)

CTG Bentonville loves our Site Manager - Stephanie Giancola!
And our Austin team too!  =; )

I LOVE that everyday CTG gives me the opportunity to make a difference.  I LOVE helping individuals find that right position, I LOVE my team, and I LOVE the fact that I work for a company that cares...  :-)
I love the fact that I have a pretty cool Site Manager!!!
Oh yeah and I work with the BEST CTG TEAM!!!! :)
